title: Leah Bracknell's brave terminal lung cancer battle after defying doctors' prognosis by years

Leah Bracknell bravely fought cancer for three years before her death, defying the odds even after her treatment stopped working.

She publicly revealed her terminal diagnosis of Stage 4 Lung Cancer in October 2016, and she lived two years longer than doctors predicted she would.

She was finally diagnosed after seeing four GPs for rapid weight gain around her abdomen and breathlessness, and was given eight months to live.

She immediately started trying cannabis oil, which helped her with the side effects of the prescription drugs she was taking.

(Image: Ken McKay/ITV/REX/Shutterstock)

Appearing on Loose Women in February, Leah said she was initially furious when she was diagnosed.

"I've talked before about how my response was one of absolute anger", she said.

"It's infuriating - how dare you tell me this - which is why I didn't want someone to guesstimate what someone thought my prognosis would be."

She added: "It's based on statistics that could be out of date, that could be not about my age, not about my specific sort of cancer.

"I don't want to be a statistic."

(Image: ITV/REX/Shutterstock)

While on the show she also revealed she was taking a new medication that she hoped would extend her life.

In summer 2018, Leah began a clinical trial after the first stage of her cancer stabilised with aggressive treatment.

She then tried a new treatment in the clinical trial to decrease the process of the disease, but this was unnsucccessful.

Fans of Leah raised £50,000 on a GoFundMe to pay for her to go to Germany to have pioneering cancer treatment there after NHS options ran out.

(Image: Leah's Cancer Fund)

She said the outpouring of support had surprised her, and thanked the donors.

"I really did not expect or feel deserving of such interest and kindness", she said.

In August this year, she announced that her treatment was not working.

She wrote on her blog: “Conventional medicine has nothing left to offer.

“Until a glimmer of hope was thrown into the ring last year with a trial placement.

“That notwithstanding, and in the face of a hope-less future, I realised that what I did have, and probably always have had, was me."

(Image: Leah Bracknell/Instagram)

During her gruelling treatment, she married her long-term partner Jez Hughes.

She told the Loose Women panel that she had a positive outlook on life and was not fearful despite being diagnosed as terminal.

She said she had formed a "relationship" with her cancer to try to understand it.

In a blog post, she explained that she was dealing with conflicted emotions.

She wrote: "Living with stage four cancer is not black and white, we cannot always be the noble and exceptional patient nor are we always self-pitying and woe-is-me ...

"To sum up, I am fed up of being fed up. And I’d like a break please."

(Image: Daily Mirror)

She continued: "I know that I have a great deal about which to be grateful.

"But that little part of me that is feeling sorry for myself just wants to be seen and heard.

"She wants to jump up and down shouting 'It’s not fair I want my life back I want to feel normal again'."

Leah also struggled with losing her independence nd most of time due to hospital appointments.

She discussed what "normal" meant to her now: "It means being able to make plans without first consulting the diary to see whether you are due to attend hospital appointments.

"Not wincing when others tell you of their plans for later in the year, and your mind finds itself begging the question, will I have the luxury of even being here later in the year?

(Image: Ken McKay/ITV/REX/Shutterstock)

"Simple stuff – driving, walking, breathing. It’d be nice to do those with ease again."

Leah was treated for an infection and was borderlining on having sepsis .

Her condition left her with fractured bones due to weakened limbs, exacerbating her already-present back pain.

During her final interview in August, she told the Mirror: "I don't need to go and fulfil a bucket list, that's not my style, I just want to do the things I want to do while I am healthy and strong.

"I won't let myself live in fear, I'm just going to live a good life."
description: Leah fought cancer hard and lived far longer than doctors predicted - through several different treatments, and finally through bravely changing her attitude to death
